feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: The review did not clearly articulate the major initiatives delivered in 2025 in a way that tied scope, outcomes, and client impact together. While account ownership and context were evident, the discussion did not sufficiently highlight what was prioritized, why it mattered, or what tangibly changed for the client as a result. Going forward, this section should focus on 2–3 clearly defined initiatives delivered in 2025 and frame them around results and impact rather than general account context.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Value creation beyond the core contract was not clearly demonstrated. The review lacked concrete examples of value-added services or cost avoidance efforts delivered in 2025, and there was limited translation of actions into operational, financial, or risk-based impact. To strengthen this area, future reviews should clearly call out specific decisions or actions that delivered incremental value and explain why those decisions mattered to the client.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Cost savings delivered in 2025 were not clearly articulated. The review did not identify ownership of cost reduction initiatives, workflow improvements, or efficiency gains. At the Account Director level, it is important to explicitly call out savings achieved, how they were created, and whether they are repeatable or one-time in nature.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: The review did not clearly demonstrate leadership in innovation or continuous improvement. While collaboration and alignment were referenced, there was limited evidence of new processes, tools, or enhancements implemented in 2025 or the results of those efforts. This section should highlight where you led change, tested new approaches, or improved how the account operates, along with the outcomes and learnings.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Challenges and gaps from 2025 were not meaningfully addressed. The review would be stronger with greater transparency around what did not go as planned, what could have been done differently, and what corrective actions were taken or are planned. Clear ownership and reflection are expected at this level.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: A clear, actionable 2026 account strategy was not fully articulated. While general intent was present, the review lacked a cohesive roadmap outlining priorities, sequencing, and how the account will be elevated through retention, growth, or differentiation. Future reviews should present a structured forward plan tied to specific initiatives and outcomes.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Personal development goals were not clearly defined or measurable. At the Account Director level, I expect clear leadership goals that demonstrate role maturity and accountability, along with an explanation of how those goals will positively impact account performance.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills: Communication was professional and clear, and engagement with senior stakeholders was appropriate. However, the discussion would benefit from a more structured, outcome-driven narrative. Executive presence is strongest when the story is concise, results-focused, and clearly connects performance, challenges, and forward strategy.

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: Mark clearly articulated meaningful initiatives delivered in 2025, particularly around account stability, scalability, and innovation. He demonstrated strong judgment in identifying what is working, where a repeatable playbook exists, and how success on his accounts can be leveraged more broadly. While the initiatives were clearly described, client impact was often implied rather than explicitly stated. This section would be further strengthened by more direct articulation of what changed for the client as a result of these initiatives and, where possible, anchoring outcomes with measurable results.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Mark provided strong examples of value creation beyond core contract scope, especially through innovation, sustainability-focused thinking, and differentiated use of existing tools such as 4insite. His commentary reflected intentional decision-making and a clear understanding of how value can be created without deviating from core SVM systems. To elevate to the highest level, Mark could further translate these value-add efforts into clearer financial, operational, or risk-based impact to reinforce the tangible benefit delivered to the client.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Mark referenced efficiency improvements and operational refinements that suggest cost discipline and improved service delivery. However, cost savings were not clearly quantified or distinguished as repeatable versus one-time improvements. This section would benefit from clearer ownership of execution and more explicit articulation of how savings were created, sustained, and leveraged over time. Even directional estimates or examples would strengthen the demonstration of financial stewardship.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: Mark demonstrated exceptional leadership in innovation and continuous improvement. His approach to leveraging existing platforms differently, building scalable playbooks, and challenging traditional execution models showed intentional experimentation, learning, and iteration. The level of interest generated from senior leadership and peers reinforces the impact and credibility of this work. Mark clearly operates with an enterprise mindset and has created innovation that is transferable beyond his immediate accounts.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Mark was transparent and self-aware in discussing the challenges of scale, particularly the need to transition from being deeply involved in innovation execution to leading through direction, playbooks, and governance. He demonstrated ownership of this gap and articulated a thoughtful reflection on what needs to change to support continued growth. To reach a 5, this section could include more explicit corrective actions with timelines tied to how Mark plans to operationalize this shift in 2026.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Mark articulated a strong forward-looking strategy centered on scalability, sustainability, and elevating successful account practices into repeatable models. The vision was cohesive and clearly connected to improving execution at scale. This section would be further strengthened by more explicit sequencing, timelines, and linkage to retention, growth, and differentiation outcomes for 2026.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Mark clearly articulated mature, leadership-level development goals focused on scaling impact, moving out of the weeds, and leading through playbooks rather than individual execution. These goals demonstrate strong role maturity, self-awareness, and readiness for increased scope. The alignment between personal development and organizational needs was particularly strong.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills: Mark communicated with confidence and credibility, demonstrating strong command of his material and an ability to engage executive audiences. His presentation sparked interest, follow-up requests, and broader organizational dialogue, which reflects effective executive presence. To elevate further, tightening structure and explicitly anchoring innovation discussions to outcomes and metrics would enhance clarity and executive-level impact.

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: Stuart clearly articulated the most important initiatives delivered in 2025 and why they mattered. His work around renewal strategy, reinvestment planning, wage structure alignment, and proactive pricing architecture demonstrated strong judgment and long-term thinking. These initiatives were intentionally executed well ahead of renewal timelines and materially reduced risk while strengthening the partnership. The linkage between initiative, outcome, and client impact was clear, particularly in how these actions positioned SBM as a trusted, forward-thinking partner rather than a reactive vendor.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Stuart demonstrated exceptional value creation beyond the contract. Rather than defaulting to cost reduction, he aligned reinvestment strategies with NVIDIA’s growth objectives and CBRE’s expectations, reinforcing trust and long-term retention. The ability to ask the right questions, confirm client intent, and then deliberately reinvest margin back into the account reflects strong commercial judgment and credibility. This is a textbook example of value creation rooted in partnership, not short-term optimization.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: While cost savings were not the primary driver for this account, Stuart clearly demonstrated financial stewardship through disciplined margin management, proactive wage forecasting, and mitigation of renewal and RFP risk. The account’s strong financial performance at scale is not accidental and reflects sustained execution. This section could be elevated further by explicitly framing how financial performance was protected over time and which practices are repeatable across other large enterprise accounts.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: Stuart showed strong leadership in continuously improving how the account is structured and managed, particularly through consolidated pricing models, early implementation of renewal strategies, and thoughtful reinvestment decisions. These improvements were practical, intentional, and outcome-oriented. To reach a 5, the next step would be documenting and formalizing these approaches into a repeatable playbook that can be leveraged across similar strategic accounts.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Stuart demonstrated maturity in how challenges were addressed, particularly around renewal risk, financial performance scrutiny, and reinvestment decisions. He showed ownership without defensiveness and made deliberate, data-backed choices aligned to client priorities. This section would be further strengthened by explicitly calling out any moments of trade-off or course correction and what was learned as a result.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Stuart articulated a clear, cohesive forward strategy tied to retention, reinvestment, and scalable growth. The 2026 vision was not abstract; it was grounded in actions already taken and partnerships already built. The sequencing, foresight, and alignment across NVIDIA and CBRE position this account for continued success and differentiation.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Stuart demonstrated strong role maturity and leadership readiness. His approach reflects an enterprise mindset, balancing financial performance, client trust, and long-term partnership value. The way he thinks about timing, reinvestment, and risk mitigation is consistent with expectations for senior Account Director leadership on marquee accounts.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills:
Stuart led the discussion with confidence, clarity, and command of the account. He presented a structured, compelling narrative and responded effectively to executive feedback and questions. His ability to communicate complex financial and strategic decisions in a clear, credible way reflects strong executive presence.

Stuart is operating at a very high level and sets a strong benchmark for strategic account leadership. The NVIDIA account is a top performer not just financially, but relationally, and that outcome reflects deliberate choices, strong judgment, and disciplined execution. The opportunity ahead is scaling this approach, codifying it, and using it as a reference model for other large enterprise accounts across the portfolio.

feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Grant showed thoughtful intent around creating value beyond the contract, particularly through efficiency gains and more deliberate use of ATB versus goodwill work. The underlying judgment and approach are strong. To improve, Grant should highlight concrete examples of value delivered in 2025 and translate those efforts into financial, operational, or risk-based impact, even at a directional level. feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Grant acknowledged the importance of efficiency and margin improvement and discussed opportunities to drive savings through workflow optimization and smarter execution. However, the review did not clearly articulate cost savings delivered in 2025, nor did it quantify or distinguish between one-time versus repeatable savings. This section would be strengthened by explicitly calling out savings achieved, describing how they were executed, and clarifying ownership and sustainability to demonstrate stronger financial stewardship.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: Grant demonstrated strong leadership in innovation and continuous improvement, particularly through forward-thinking exploration of AI-enabled decision support and data-driven contract and ATB optimization. The willingness to test, learn, and potentially scale new tools reflects a proactive and enterprise-minded approach. To reach the highest level, this section would benefit from clearer linkage to pilots, experiments, or early outcomes in 2025, along with lessons learned that inform next steps.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Grant showed transparency in acknowledging the importance of maintaining operational stability while pursuing growth and recognized the inherent challenges that come with scaling. There was a clear sense of ownership and awareness of risk. To further strengthen this section, Grant could deepen reflection by explicitly calling out specific challenges faced in 2025, what could have been done differently, and outlining corrective actions or guardrails with clearer timelines.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Grant articulated a clear, compelling, and well-prioritized 2026 forward strategy focused on revenue growth, leadership development, cross-campus collaboration, and enterprise capability expansion. The strategy was proactive, cohesive, and strongly connected to retention, growth, and differentiation. The vision demonstrated strong judgment, sequencing, and scalability, with clear intent to elevate both the account and broader organizational capabilities.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Grant clearly defined thoughtful, leadership-level professional goals that align strongly with Account Director expectations and demonstrate role maturity. The goals were forward-looking, measurable in intent, and focused on developing leaders, improving margins, and driving enterprise-level impact. Grant demonstrated a strong growth mindset and readiness to operate at increased scope and influence.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills: Grant communicated confidently and demonstrated strong command of the material, clearly articulating priorities and responding effectively to executive feedback. The discussion had logical flow and depth, and executive presence was evident throughout. To elevate further, Grant could tighten pacing and sharpen storytelling around outcomes and impact to ensure maximum clarity and resonance with senior executive audiences.

feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: With a strong focus on larger accounts within the Google portfolio and the successful implementation of program enhancements, is there an opportunity to scale these single-site offerings across the broader portfolio? feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: This portion of the presentation felt broadly outlined and lacked the specifics needed to provide deeper insight into the challenges and opportunities. The statement, ‘We need to figure out a way to drive innovation and the speed of innovation,’ without identifying the roadblocks or challenges, leaves much open to interpretation. Have we sought support to address these issues? As leaders and partners, managing accounts holistically is part of our role. A clearer understanding of why this is a challenge would be valuable. Are communication gaps with our partners contributing to this? Were we waiting for them to initiate? There seemed to be a lot left unsaid.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: I appreciated the emphasis on aligning with our partner around a shared vision. However, what does that vision entail? What does true alignment look like? Forward looking innovation was mentioned, but the specifics were unclear. What exactly are we innovating? The passion to support our partner and elevate value to Google came through strongly, which is greatly appreciated. What was missing were the concrete details: what steps we will take, how we will execute them, and the timeline for delivery.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: The goals presented are commendable and will undoubtedly add value to our programs, team members, and partners. However, how will these goals be measured, and how is success defined? They felt more team and program oriented than personal, which is valuable, but I would also love to understand Paul’s personal goals.  What does he hope to achieve and what is the impact he envisions?
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills: Considering Paul’s relatively short tenure and limited time on the account, he did a fantastic job. However, references to his brief time, such as explicitly stating it upfront, seemed to be his desire lower expectations for the presentation. Removing those mentions would have strengthened the delivery and conveyed greater confidence. With more time on the account, I believe many of the gaps noted in the presentation will naturally be addressed, given the strength of his talking points and overall presentation. Gaining full account awareness will be a key advantage for him moving forward.

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: Paul articulated several meaningful initiatives underway across the Google portfolio, including the shift toward a more intentional, unified account strategy, demand-based cleaning pilots, enhanced cleaning programs, and scope expansion through competitor displacement. The initiatives themselves were relevant and well selected. However, the framing leaned more toward describing what was happening or what partners were asking for rather than clearly articulating the outcomes those initiatives were designed to achieve. To strengthen this section, Paul should more explicitly define the objective behind each initiative, what success looks like for the client, and what changed or will change as a result.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Paul demonstrated awareness of how value can be created through improved alignment, reduced noise, and more predictable outcomes for the client. There were clear signals of partnership and responsiveness to JLL and Google priorities. That said, value adds and cost avoidance were largely described at a conceptual level. Going forward, this section would benefit from clearer examples of deliberate decisions or actions taken that delivered incremental value beyond the contract, and from translating those efforts into operational, financial, or risk-reduction impact.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: While efficiency and demand-based models were discussed, cost savings delivered in 2025 were not clearly articulated or quantified. There was limited clarity on ownership of savings, execution details, or whether improvements are repeatable versus pilot-based. Given Paul’s tenure, this is understandable, but as he moves into a full operating year, I would expect clearer articulation of cost savings achieved, how they were driven, and how they will be sustained without eroding service quality or partnership trust.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: Paul demonstrated a willingness to challenge the status quo and explore new operating models, particularly through right-time cleaning, enhanced cleaning programs, and pilot approaches at Westlake. These efforts reflect the right mindset. To elevate this further, future reviews should more clearly differentiate between ideas being tested versus innovations already delivering results, and capture lessons learned that inform broader rollout or course correction.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Paul acknowledged real challenges across the Google portfolio, including operational noise, siloed execution, and partner-driven change requests. There was openness around tension points, particularly where efficiency initiatives could impact flexibility or responsiveness. To strengthen this section, Paul should more explicitly state what he would do differently, where trade-offs were made, and what corrective actions or guardrails he plans to put in place with clear timelines.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Paul articulated a general forward-looking direction focused on unifying the account view, improving predictability, and scaling successful initiatives across regions. The intent is sound, but the strategy would benefit from sharper definition. Moving forward, I would expect a clearer 2026 roadmap that outlines priorities, sequencing, and how these initiatives directly support retention, growth, and differentiation for Google.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Paul demonstrated appropriate self-awareness given his short time in role and showed a thoughtful approach to learning the portfolio and relationships. Personal development goals, however, were not yet clearly articulated or measurable. As Paul settles into the role, I would expect clearer leadership goals tied to account outcomes, team alignment, and execution discipline.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills:
Paul communicated clearly and professionally and demonstrated comfort engaging with senior stakeholders. Executive presence is developing, and confidence will naturally increase with tenure. To elevate further, tightening the narrative around outcomes, ownership, and decision rationale will help Paul lead executive-level discussions with greater authority and clarity.

Paul is in a reasonable ramp phase and is demonstrating the right instincts around strategy, partnership, and modernization of the Google account. The primary opportunity moving into 2026 is sharpening outcome-based framing, clearly defining ownership versus partner-driven initiatives, and translating strategy into measurable results. With greater clarity on the “why” behind initiatives and more explicit articulation of impact, Paul is well positioned to strengthen his effectiveness and influence over the next year.

feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills:

Kimberly delivered a strong review that demonstrated ownership, sound judgment, and effective execution within a highly constrained environment. The opportunity going forward is sharpening outcome-based storytelling and clearly framing impact, scalability, and lessons learned to consistently land at a 5 level.

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: Aaron clearly articulated the operating model and outcomes for the 3M account, with a strong emphasis on stability, safety, and consistency. While there were no major transformational initiatives delivered in 2025, Aaron demonstrated sound judgment in prioritizing operational discipline and reliability given the size and scope of the account. To elevate this section, future reviews should more explicitly frame initiatives as deliberate leadership decisions, including why maintaining a “model site” was strategically important and how that approach could translate into broader client or portfolio impact.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Aaron effectively highlighted cost avoidance through recordable-free operations, low turnover, and a lean staffing model, all of which contribute to reduced risk and operational noise for the client. The value narrative is directionally strong, particularly around avoided incidents and stability. To strengthen this further, Aaron should more consistently quantify value adds and clearly distinguish between baseline performance and intentional value delivered beyond contract expectations.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Aaron demonstrated an understanding of indirect cost savings through incident avoidance, reduced overtime, and minimized retraining costs. While these savings were not formally tracked or deeply quantified, the rationale was credible and aligned to the operating model. This section would benefit from clearer articulation of how savings are measured, sustained, and repeatable, particularly if the 3M model is intended to be scaled to more complex accounts.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: The 3M account was intentionally managed with a “no surprises” mindset, which is appropriate given its scope and revenue profile. However, innovation and continuous improvement were largely framed as maintaining discipline rather than testing or implementing new processes. Looking ahead, Aaron has an opportunity to demonstrate leadership by extracting learnings from this model site and actively applying them to higher-complexity accounts or broader portfolio improvements.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Aaron was transparent in acknowledging the primary limitation of the 3M account: constrained growth and limited opportunity for value expansion. He demonstrated clear ownership of those realities without deflection and showed thoughtful reflection on what the account is and is not designed to deliver. This level of clarity and accountability is a strength and reflects sound leadership maturity.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Aaron articulated a clear and appropriate forward strategy for 2026, positioning 3M as a benchmark or model account rather than forcing artificial growth. His plan to leverage the account as a governance, safety, and operational playbook for more complex portfolios shows strong judgment. To reach a top score, future plans should include more explicit sequencing and examples of how insights from 3M will be operationalized elsewhere.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Aaron defined clear personal goals tied to account performance, including maintaining zero reportables, improving audit performance, and formally showcasing the account as a best-practice example. These goals demonstrate role maturity, accountability, and a growth mindset. Continued focus on expanding impact beyond individual sites will further strengthen leadership readiness.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills: Aaron led the discussion with clarity, confidence, and a structured narrative. He demonstrated strong command of the data and consistently tied operational details back to outcomes that matter to executive stakeholders. With continued refinement around concise storytelling and sharper framing of strategic decisions, Aaron’s executive presence will continue to strengthen.

feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Justin demonstrated strong role maturity, particularly in managing complex portfolios, developing leaders, and making tough operational decisions. His emphasis on proactive service, talent development, and consistency reflects a growth mindset. Making personal development goals more explicit and measurable would further strengthen this section.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills:

Continued refinement toward more concise executive-level framing and sharper quantification of impact will further elevate his presence.

Justin delivered a strong 2025 performance across a complex, high-visibility portfolio. His strengths lie in execution, leadership development, and proactive value creation. Gaining trust was a key sentence that you said. It has been hard to manage Sodexo successfully. We provided the savings proposal even if we didnt have to execute the removal of 44 people. It will be a win at anything less than 30%. I would like to have seen more on the optimization proposals with some depth to service delivery impacts.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: Merck rejected our innovation due to GDP gap. How can we overcome this? (see note in 2026 goals) Is there a way to get 4i GDP approved? Centralized trash had a very big impact this could be a case study shared amongst the ops team.

Need to fill the Sr Site Manager role with the proper Site Manager by tier. I would like to understand the resolve of several things on your issues. How will we overcome the challenges?
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: I really appreciate you having a clear outline to growth.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity:
2026 Goal - POC Rosanna or whomever involved and educated our our scorecard process. MIT Training - mentoring and training someone at all times. Get work releases. Needs to be clearl defined measurable goals. 
Missing 2026 Goals
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills: Overall I thought you presented well, I felt your knowledge of the material and account. I can appreciate the challenges as well as building a relationship with Sodexo and how hard that probably has been. To have gotten more credit I would like to have seen things flushed out more with solutions, to issues or challenges, depth to the value we bring. While you clearly articulated the what in what we have done I felt the impact to Merck was missing. What about us is different or better than our competitors? Why does Merck continue to chose us not just because we do what they ask but the value we bring what is that? Your notes were a helpful guide but you relied heavily on them, however, when asked you were able to provide more details which I appreciated. I challenge you to know the value, the why, and command the room wit authority over your material you have done great things - brag about it :)

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: David led and owned a highly complex site consolidation, transitioning Merck operations from Kenilworth and Madison into Rahway and effectively supporting the establishment of Rahway as the new headquarters. The increase in headcount from ~3,000 to ~6,500 without business disruption, union grievances, or work stoppages is a meaningful operational achievement. David clearly demonstrated ownership, coordination across multiple stakeholders, and disciplined execution. This was a strong section and appropriately positioned as a major 2025 accomplishment.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: David articulated several operational value adds, particularly around continuity of service, stakeholder engagement, and maintaining quality during a major transition. While the operational discipline was evident, the articulation of value leaned more toward effort than impact. This section would be strengthened by more explicitly tying value adds to outcomes Merck cares about, such as risk mitigation, employee experience, or avoided disruption during consolidation.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Cost savings were clearly identified and quantified, most notably the $404K reduction achieved through optimization of ABW and portering services. David did a solid job explaining how service levels and SLAs were preserved despite reduced hours, reinforcing credibility. This was one of the stronger sections of the review and demonstrated both financial discipline and operational stewardship.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: The initiatives presented were largely optimization-driven rather than innovative, but they were appropriate given the scale of the transition and the maturity of the account. David showed an understanding of how to evolve service models to match Merck’s flexible workplace strategy. To elevate this section, future reviews should highlight lessons learned, repeatable playbooks, or process improvements that can be scaled beyond Rahway.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: David acknowledged the complexity and risk inherent in the consolidation effort and demonstrated accountability for overseeing the entire project. He was transparent about the challenges and showed confidence in the controls and governance used to manage them. This section reflected solid ownership and credibility as an account leader.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: David referenced continued optimization and operational stability but did not fully articulate a forward-looking strategy beyond maintaining performance and cost discipline. A clearer 2026 narrative around growth opportunities, service evolution, or deeper strategic partnership with Merck would strengthen this section.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: While David demonstrated maturity and confidence in his role, personal development goals were not explicitly articulated. Future reviews would benefit from clearer articulation of leadership growth objectives or areas of focus tied to expanding scope or complexity.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills:
David was composed, professional, and knowledgeable, and he handled questions appropriately. At times, responses could be more crisply framed around business outcomes rather than operational details. Sharpening executive storytelling and proactively answering the “why it matters” will elevate his presence with senior audiences.

David delivered a strong operational review anchored by a significant, well-executed consolidation effort and tangible cost savings. His strengths lie in execution, ownership, and operational discipline. The next step in his development is sharpening outcome-based storytelling and articulating a more forward-looking strategic narrative. Overall, this was a solid performance that reflects a dependable and capable account leader.

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: Rade clearly identified the major 2025 initiatives within his scope as Interim Account Manager, particularly the implementation of return-to-office readiness, night route realignment, workload balancing, and improved management systems. These efforts were necessary and appropriately prioritized given the account’s state. To strengthen this section, future articulation should more clearly frame these initiatives in terms of client impact and outcomes, not just execution, and explicitly distinguish between baseline operational requirements and discretionary leadership decision
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Learning curve acknowledged - Rade demonstrated thoughtful intent around value creation through improved visibility, transparency, and partnership with CBRE. These efforts helped stabilize operations and reduce friction across teams. However, value adds were described more qualitatively than quantitatively. To elevate this section, Rade should translate these improvements into clearer operational, financial, or risk-avoidance outcomes that matter to the client.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Cost savings were not clearly articulated as discrete outcomes in 2025. While route optimization and workload balancing likely contributed to efficiency, this section would benefit from clearer ownership of savings delivered, avoided costs, or sustained efficiencies. Even directional estimates or examples of disciplined cost control would strengthen credibility here.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: Rade showed a practical approach to continuous improvement by implementing management systems that improved visibility and accountability and strengthened the partnership with CBRE. While these changes were more evolutionary than innovative, they were appropriate for the role and timing. To reach a higher rating, future reviews should highlight lessons learned, measurable improvements, and how these practices can be standardized or scaled.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Rade demonstrated transparency and accountability in acknowledging the constraints of the role and the operational realities of the account. He communicated challenges clearly and focused on corrective actions within his control. This section reflected maturity and credibility. Adding clearer timelines and success metrics for corrective actions would further strengthen accountability signaling.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Rade outlined a logical forward direction focused on continued stabilization, stronger management systems, and improved alignment with CBRE. The strategy was appropriate given the interim nature of the role. To elevate this section, future articulation should include clearer prioritization and sequencing, particularly around how the account will be positioned for long-term success beyond interim leadership.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Rade demonstrated professionalism, composure, and growth readiness in stepping into an interim leadership role. Personal development goals, however, were not clearly articulated. Going forward, defining measurable leadership objectives tied to execution rigor, communication, and decision-making would strengthen this section.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills:
Rade communicated enthusiastically, calmly and professionally and handled the discussion with openness despite technical challenges. While the presentation lacked polish at times, he maintained composure and stayed focused on the substance. Continued practice around executive storytelling, sharper framing of outcomes, and more confident pacing will meaningfully elevate his presence.

performed well within the expectations of an interim Account Manager, prioritizing stability, transparency, and partnership during a period of operational need. His strengths are accountability, practicality, and steady leadership. The next level of growth will come from sharper outcome framing, clearer quantification of impact, and more confident executive communication. With continued development, Rade shows solid potential to take on expanded responsibility.

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: Greg highlighted the successful five-year contract renewal as the anchor achievement for 2025, which is a meaningful outcome given Abbott’s focus on cost discipline and prior years of optimization. He also referenced selective scope growth and the onboarding of a new site mid-January. While these are relevant initiatives, they were presented in a bundled manner that made it harder to clearly distinguish “projects” versus financial outcomes. This section would benefit from sharper separation and clearer framing of why each initiative mattered strategically to Abbott.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Greg called out approximately $14K in cost avoidance at Abbott Park, funded by SBM to strengthen the relationship at the headquarters location. The intent and outcome were positive, and the initiative appears to have delivered relationship value. However, the broader value narrative leaned heavily toward financial mechanics rather than client impact. Elevating this section with clearer linkage to stakeholder trust, risk reduction, or long-term renewal confidence would strengthen the message.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Greg provided helpful context around why cost savings were more limited in 2025, noting that Abbott had already realized significant savings in prior years. He demonstrated alignment with the client’s expectations and explained how right-sizing and model adjustments maintained savings within Abbott’s pricing framework. While the explanation was sound, the delivery could be more concise and outcome-focused, with clearer articulation of how SBM helped Abbott sustain savings without compromising service.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: Innovation was not a central theme in the presentation, which Greg appropriately acknowledged given the account’s maturity and prior cost-cutting cycles. That said, the section would benefit from highlighting incremental improvements, governance refinements, or process changes that show continuous evolution even in a stabilized account.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Greg demonstrated awareness of the constraints on cost savings and showed alignment with Abbott’s financial posture. He took accountability for managing within those limits and avoided over-promising. This was a steady, credible section, though it could be strengthened by explicitly naming key risks and how they were mitigated during the renewal year.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: The forward-looking narrative was present but understated. Greg referenced continued alignment and stability but did not clearly outline a proactive strategy for 2026 beyond maintaining the current model. A stronger vision around relationship expansion, targeted value creation, or strategic differentiation would elevate this section.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Personal development goals were not explicitly articulated. Greg presents as steady and experienced, but future reviews would benefit from clearer self-reflection on growth areas or leadership objectives tied to the account’s next phase.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills:
Greg was calm, credible, and clearly knowledgeable about the account. At times, content was bundled in a way that blurred sections, which made it harder for the audience to track against the rubric. Tightening structure and clearly signposting each section would materially improve executive clarity. 

Greg delivered a solid, credible review anchored by a successful long-term contract renewal and disciplined financial stewardship. His strength lies in stability, alignment, and managing mature accounts with constrained cost levers. The primary opportunity is sharpening structure and storytelling to clearly separate projects, value, and outcomes, and to articulate a more forward-leaning strategy for 2026. Overall, this was a dependable performance that reflects steady account leadership.

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: Luis clearly articulated a small number of high-impact initiatives that mattered deeply to the client. He demonstrated strong judgment in prioritizing GMP compliance, FDA inspection readiness, and SOP modernization, and clearly explained why these efforts were critical to Takeda’s risk profile and long-term operations. The narrative was outcome-driven, showed ownership end-to-end, and made it clear what changed for the client as a result of the work.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Luis delivered exceptional examples of value beyond contract scope. He translated operational improvements into tangible financial, sustainability, and risk-reduction outcomes, including meaningful cost avoidance, waste reduction, and regulatory confidence. The work demonstrated intentional decision-making, proactive partnership, and a clear understanding of how to align SBM’s efforts with Takeda’s strategic priorities.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Cost savings were clearly articulated, quantified, and tied to repeatable process improvements rather than one-time actions. Luis showed strong ownership of execution, from SOP redesign through testing, implementation, and hypercare. The savings were framed in a way that demonstrated long-term sustainability and strong financial stewardship, reinforcing SBM’s role as a trusted operational partn
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: Luis demonstrated meaningful innovation within a highly regulated environment, which is notably difficult to do well. His ability to influence SOP changes after a decade, introduce reusable materials, and advance sustainability programs reflects mature leadership, credibility with the client, and continuous improvement thinking. Innovation was practical, scalable, and client-centric.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Luis acknowledged the increased complexity and risk associated with higher compliance requirements and increased documentation volume, and clearly owned the operational response. He demonstrated accountability by explaining how risk was actively managed rather than avoided. This section would be further strengthened by briefly highlighting one or two lessons learned that could be applied to other GMP accounts.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Luis presented a clear forward-looking strategy tied to electronic logbooks, continued sustainability leadership, and deeper operational partnership. The path forward felt intentional and aligned with Takeda’s trajectory. This section could be elevated by explicitly calling out how SBM will scale or replicate these wins across other regulated accounts.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Luis demonstrated strong role maturity through the way he spoke about partnership, accountability, and long-term impact. While personal development goals were not explicitly outlined, his ownership of complex, high-risk initiatives signals readiness for increased scope. Articulating personal growth objectives would further strengthen future reviews.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills:
The strongest, most structured presentations across the group (so far). His visuals were clear, his narrative was disciplined, and his delivery balanced confidence with credibility. He communicated complex regulatory and operational topics in a way that was accessible, compelling, and executive-ready.

Luis delivered an exceptional year-end review that exemplifies what strong account leadership looks like in a regulated, high-stakes environment. He demonstrated clear ownership, strategic thinking, and the ability to translate complex work into meaningful client outcomes. This was a best-in-class performance and a strong benchmark for GMP and enterprise accounts moving forward.

feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills:
Scott has made this hard landing look easy for those on the outside or have not been apart of this from the beginning. Sanofi was not an easy account, it was bid very aggressively from a financial standpoint. On top of an extremely complex environment with GMP and new program with Slurry. From the start, Scott owned it. He transitioned it seamlessly and have managed it exceptionally well.

What really stood out to me is that it didn’t suck the life out of the SLT team and that says a lot. That doesn’t happen often. You consistently provided updates the good, the bad, and the ugly and regardless of the challenge, you came with a solution. You didn’t just bring problems up; you solved them.

Most importantly, you’re a trusted advisor for both SBM and the client. While all ADs are empowered, in this case it genuinely showed. as said in the presentation they have been very reluctant to make a change.

Everything you have done for the last 12 months has positioned you and SBM very well for the growth. Excited to see those results in 2026!

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: I think there's an opportunity to tie more of our initiatives to our customer's goals in order to better define impact. One public example, waste reduction. Micron is targeting 95% diversion from landfill. If our sustainability initiative is to use cores of paper towels, etc. toward reuse but ultimately they still end up in the landfill, our initiative may be slightly misaligned with Micron's overall goal. Maybe we target dual roll dispensers from GP that automatically dispense a second roll towel when the first roll depletes, encouraging full utilization of that stub roll. Tork Peakserve is another potential option. I think you gave some compelling examples of initiatives (plate scraping, etc) that have real impact on the client's goals. Just want to encourage more communication around what the client's specific goals are, even searching publicly available information, and crafting our initiatives and messaging around how we can impact them.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Provided strong examples of value creation with diretional financial framing. I LOVED that you called out window cleaning cost savings leading to enhanced service performance at the SJC site. We tend to forget about "savings" like this that don't result in YOY impact, but the fact that funds were able to be pivoted into other customer priorities with SBM is exactly the kind of cost savings we want to drive. Savings on urinal mats and other initiatives could be quanitifed, tightened. But each was a compelling example.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Regarding value-added work, I'm not sure there was a quantified amount that we delivered to the client in SJC, which makes me wonder if the client understands the value of our reinvestment into that site. It's 100% OK to deliver a project at no charge or at cost, better if the client knows they're getting something for free, and best for the client to know (and be reminded of) the estimated values of of the work we've done for them. Again, thought you had strong examples here, I just wonder if we could tighten up some of the quantified impact.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: Mentioned this on the call, but I love that you are leaning into areas where the company has limited playbook for you to go off of (construction cleaning, MAC work, event support, & more). You're helping write the playbook, and I think that's impressive and commendable.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: We trust your assessment that the gaps in SJC were largely due to a demanding client. This may have glazed over some of the real misses down there, and opportunities for improvement. The end result is that you managed the account and led the team to right wrongs and improe our service. Just think there may have been more room for partial ownership of challenges down there, and that honestly they would have done nothing but strengthen your already strong credibility on the call.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Love the tenacity on Micron Singapore. Second the feedback of others regarding intermediate steps, or the bite-size chunks you'll be taking along the way. I think others were concerned about time-bound goals, I'd encourage more thinking around what needs to happen, in sequence, for your big vision to take effect, and road-mapping that for SLT.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Feedback previously given regarding time-bound goals, but I think you had a strong vision for where the account can and will be in 2027 and I very much look forward to seeing and helping you achieve it.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills: Discussion was led with confidence and authority, with a well-constructed story of achievements on the account. Your presentation style is engaging and easy to interact with.

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: You key projects also highlighted your challenges and changes. I appreciate how you didnt just discuss the activity, but the results from changes we made.

Key Projects & Initiatives.definition: Evaluates ability to articulate meaningful work and outcomes

criteria.5: Clearly frames the most important 2025 initiatives, why they mattered, and what changed for the client as a result; demonstrates strong judgment, prioritization, and impact awareness
criteria.4: Presents a clear narrative of key initiatives and outcomes, with minor gaps in impact clarity or measurement
criteria.3: Accurately describes initiatives but focuses more on execution than client outcomes or strategic impact
criteria.2: Mentions projects but lacks ownership, prioritization, or clarity on why they mattered
criteria.1: Unable to clearly articulate major initiatives or their relevance

Value Adds & Cost Avoidance.definition: Evaluates ability to demonstrate value beyond contract scope

criteria.5: Clearly articulates value delivered beyond contract scope and translates it into estimated financial, operational, or risk-based impact
criteria.4: Provides strong examples of value creation with partial or directional financial framing
criteria.3: Describes value adds but does not translate them into financial or business impact
criteria.2: Examples are vague or lack clarity on value delivered

Cost Savings Delivered.definition: Evaluates financial stewardship and operational efficiency

criteria.5: Clearly explains how cost savings were created, quantified, and sustained; demonstrates strong financial stewardship
criteria.4: Identifies cost savings with reasonable clarity and some indication of sustainability
criteria.3: Mentions cost savings but with limited explanation or primarily one-time impact
criteria.2: Savings referenced without clear understanding, ownership, or credibility

Innovation & Continuous Improvement.definition: Evaluates leadership in evolving service delivery

criteria.5: Demonstrates intentional innovation or meaningful pivots, with clear outcomes and lessons learned
criteria.4: Introduced improvements or adaptations that positively impacted the account
criteria.3: Participated in improvement efforts but with limited leadership or ownership
criteria.2: Discusses ideas or concepts without execution or demonstrated impact
criteria.1: No evidence of innovation or continuous improvement

Issues, Challenges & Accountability.definition: Evaluates self-awareness, ownership, and executive leadership

criteria.5: Fully transparent about challenges, clearly owns gaps, and outlines specific corrective actions with timelines
criteria.4: Identifies challenges and discusses improvement actions with reasonable clarity
criteria.3: Acknowledges issues but provides limited reflection, ownership, or follow-through
criteria.2: Defensive, vague, or minimizes challenges without accountability
criteria.1: Avoids or fails to address challenges altogether

2026 Forward Strategy & Vision.definition: Evaluates strategic thinking and future readiness

criteria.5: Articulates a clear, compelling 2026 account roadmap tied to retention, growth, and differentiation, with defined priorities and sequencing
criteria.4: Presents a strong forward-looking plan with reasonable clarity and timelines
criteria.3: Shares general goals or aspirations without clear execution detail
criteria.2: Strategy is reactive, unclear, or lacks cohesion

Personal Goals & Role Maturity.definition: Evaluates professional growth and role ownership

criteria.5: Clearly defines measurable leadership goals that demonstrate role maturity, accountability, and impact on account performance
criteria.4: Establishes thoughtful goals with progress and clearly articulated next steps
criteria.3: Shares general development intentions without clear measures or ownership
criteria.2: Goals are vague, unclear, or not actionable
criteria.1: No articulated leadership or development goals

Executive Presence & Presentation Skills.definition: Evaluates effectiveness in delivering the review to executive leadership

criteria.5: Leads the discussion with confidence and authority; presents a clear, structured account narrative and responds effectively to executive questions
criteria.4: Communicates clearly with logical flow; delivers a cohesive account story with minor gaps in executive presence or impact
criteria.3: Communicates key points but relies heavily on prepared material; executive presence is limited
criteria.2: Communication lacks clarity or structure; executive presence is inconsistent
criteria.1: Unable to effectively lead the discussion at an executive level

Benjamin Ehrenberg.title: Quantifying Value-Adds Methodology
Benjamin Ehrenberg.description: Repeatable framework for tracking gratuitous services with dollar figures (frequent setups, escort avoidance, out-of-scope work)
Benjamin Ehrenberg.context: At Lockheed Martin, Ben needed to demonstrate value beyond base contract scope. The challenge: clients see routine service execution as 'just doing your job,' not as added value. Ben created a systematic framework to track and quantify all gratuitous services with actual dollar figures - things like frequent last-minute setups, escort avoidance, and out-of-scope work that other vendors would charge for. This transforms client perception from 'meeting expectations' to 'delivering measurable partnership value.' Leadership explicitly challenged Ben to implement this in 2026 as it provides powerful retention ammunition during renewals by showing documented cost avoidance.
Benjamin Ehrenberg.impact: Demonstrates true partnership value; provides retention ammunition during renewals

Mark Schlerf.title: Gap Analysis as Strategic Opportunity Framework
Mark Schlerf.description: Turn CBRE Lam Research gap analysis (potential minefield showing contract vs. actual performance) into strategic investment opportunities by showing 'what is different by location and what the opportunities are' for client to fund improvements
Mark Schlerf.context: When CBRE asked Mark to conduct a gap analysis at Lam Research comparing contract language to actual performance across sites, it could have been a landmine - exposing service deficiencies and creating ammunition for price reduction or termination. Instead, Mark strategically reframed it as an opportunity identification exercise. He showed 'what is different by location' and presented the gaps as investment opportunities for the client to fund scope improvements. This turned a potential liability into a value conversation, positioning SBM as a strategic partner rather than a vendor under scrutiny. Nick Viskovich praised this approach as a masterclass in strategic thinking.
Mark Schlerf.impact: Converted potential liability into client investment in scope improvements

Mark Schlerf.title: JLL Quarterly Operations Reviews Cadence
Mark Schlerf.description: Structured quarterly review process with IFM partners to align on performance, innovation, and growth
Mark Schlerf.context: Mark established a disciplined quarterly review cadence with JLL as the IFM partner across his portfolio. These aren't reactive check-ins but proactive strategic sessions covering performance metrics, innovation roadmaps, and growth opportunities. This governance model has strengthened the IFM relationship to the point where renewals happen off-market without competitive bidding. Nick Viskovich noted this as a replicable best practice that creates predictability and reduces client anxiety while positioning SBM as an indispensable strategic partner rather than a transactional vendor.
Mark Schlerf.impact: Strengthened IFM relationships; secured off-market renewals
Mark Schlerf.leadership_endorsement: Nick Viskovich noted as strong governance model

Grant Frazier.title: Luna's Standard Cadence for Transitions
Grant Frazier.description: Standardized weekly client update process for transitions; drove all standard processes forward systematically
Grant Frazier.context: When Meta awarded SBM two massive new campuses (Fremont and Sunnyvale totaling $800K in new revenue), Grant's operations manager Luna created a systematic weekly client update framework specifically for transitions. The process included standardized checkpoints: staffing status, quality metrics, client feedback loops, issue resolution, and next week's priorities. This disciplined cadence stabilized Fremont in just 1.5 months and Sunnyvale in 3 months - remarkably fast for sites of this scale. Grant openly credited Luna: 'I wouldn't have done that without Luna's ability to make those standards.' Leadership praised this as a replicable playbook for all future transitions to reduce client anxiety and accelerate revenue stabilization.
Grant Frazier.impact: Stabilized Fremont in 1.5 months, Sunnyvale in 3 months; Grant: 'I wouldn't have done that without Luna's ability to make those standards'
Grant Frazier.leadership_endorsement: Grant explicitly credited Luna; Val/Nick praised execution

Grant Frazier.title: Sub-Tenant Day Porter Revenue Model
Grant Frazier.description: Strategic placement of day porters for sub-tenants in property management buildings; positions SBM as exclusive provider
Grant Frazier.context: In property management buildings (like Meta's San Francisco HQ at SF181), Grant identified untapped revenue: sub-tenants (Klavio, Mercor) wanted dedicated day porter services but had no direct facilities relationship. Traditional vendors only serve the building owner. Grant positioned SBM as the exclusive provider to ALL building occupants, adding 3.5 FTE day porters serving multiple sub-tenants for $34K in incremental revenue. This micro-innovation model is portable to any multi-tenant building nationally and demonstrates SBM's strategic thinking beyond traditional janitorial scope. Nick Viskovich praised this as differentiated business development thinking.
Grant Frazier.impact: $34k revenue from 3.5 FTE; client sees consolidation value

Stuart Kelloff.title: 12-Month Renewal Planning Strategy
Stuart Kelloff.description: Plan NVIDIA renewal throughout all of 2025 for April 2026 expiration (not just last 3-4 months); consistent implementation of reinvestment practices throughout the year
Stuart Kelloff.context: Most Account Directors plan renewals 3-4 months before expiration, leading to last-minute scrambles and client skepticism. Stuart took a radically different approach for NVIDIA's April 2026 renewal: he planned throughout ALL of 2025, implementing consistent reinvestment practices as an operating rhythm rather than a 'renewal push.' This means tiered wage increases, equipment upgrades, and governance improvements happened steadily all year. The result: NVIDIA positioned to renew early in February (2 months ahead), avoided RFP risk, and is now going on year 9 with SBM (3rd consecutive renewal). Leadership gave this approach 5/5 scores and cited it as a best practice for de-risking renewals and building genuine partnerships.
Stuart Kelloff.impact: Positioned for early renewal in February; mitigated RFP; going on year 9 with SBM (3rd consecutive renewal)
Stuart Kelloff.leadership_endorsement: Valarie Barnett praised; Nick Viskovich gave 5/5

Stuart Kelloff.title: Tiered Wage Rate Structure / Frontline Reinvestment
Stuart Kelloff.description: Ground-up wage structure from starting to experienced employees; reinvest margin into team vs client cost reduction
Stuart Kelloff.context: For NVIDIA's renewal, Stuart worked with the client to create a tiered wage rate structure built from the ground up - differentiating starting employees from experienced staff. Instead of taking margin to the bottom line or reducing client costs, Stuart reinvested the savings back into the frontline team through wage increases and career progression pathways. NVIDIA saw this as partnership behavior rather than profit extraction. The client explicitly wanted this reinvestment approach as part of the renewal strategy. Nick Viskovich gave this 5/5 for value-add, noting it improves retention, reduces training costs, and positions SBM as an employer of choice.
Stuart Kelloff.impact: Retention improved; client sees partnership value; positioned for renewal success

Stuart Kelloff.title: Weekly Scorecard Reviews with Client
Stuart Kelloff.description: Structured weekly review cadence with NVIDIA/CBRE on performance metrics, safety, quality
Stuart Kelloff.context: Stuart established a structured weekly (not monthly, not quarterly) scorecard review with NVIDIA and CBRE covering performance metrics, safety incidents, quality scores, and upcoming initiatives. This creates a predictable rhythm where issues surface early and get resolved before they escalate. It also demonstrates transparency and partnership commitment that monthly reviews can't match. Leadership noted this as a governance best practice that reduces client complaints by 60%+, strengthens partnership perception, and serves as an early warning system. The discipline of weekly reviews forces operational excellence and eliminates the 'hoping problems go away' trap.
Stuart Kelloff.impact: Proactive issue identification; strengthened trust; reduced surprises
Stuart Kelloff.leadership_endorsement: Leadership noted as governance best practice

Jacqueline Maravilla.title: Non-Routine to ATB Budget Conversion
Jacqueline Maravilla.description: Identified non-routine work orders consuming SOW headcount; met with customer and got approval to pull non-routine onto above-the-base
Jacqueline Maravilla.context: At Alonza, Jacqueline's budget was persistently red despite hitting service levels. Deep analysis revealed non-routine work orders (urgent cleanings, emergency responses, GMP area shutdowns) were consuming SOW headcount budget but weren't being billed separately - classic scope creep. She met directly with the Alonza customer and proposed moving all non-routine work to above-the-base billing. The client agreed, generating $6K/month in sustained additional revenue while freeing up SOW headcount for actual routine work. This systematic approach to scope management turned the account from red to green and protected margins without sacrificing service quality. Nick Viskovich and Dan Hartman praised this as a replicable methodology for identifying hidden revenue.
Jacqueline Maravilla.impact: $6k/month sustained additional revenue; freed up SOW headcount for routine work; resolved budget red status
Jacqueline Maravilla.leadership_endorsement: Nick Viskovich praised; Dan Hartman noted financial impact

Paul Rhodes.title: Holistic Account Strategy (Unifying Silos)
Paul Rhodes.description: Unite siloed regional operations (Bay Area vs Americas) into one holistic view; initiatives flow between regions; Seattle POCs had 'no idea' about Bay Area innovations
Paul Rhodes.context: Google's operations are siloed by region - Bay Area and Americas operate independently with separate QBRs and strategies. Paul discovered Seattle POCs had 'no idea' about innovations happening in the Bay Area, and vice versa. JLL doesn't communicate internally across regions, so Paul is intentionally positioning himself as the connector, creating one unified Google view. This means initiatives can flow between regions, decision-making becomes more informed, and there are fewer surprises. Paul's goal for 2026-2027 is to unite these silos completely, creating enterprise visibility and alignment that JLL can't provide. Leadership acknowledged this strategic gap and praised Paul for identifying the opportunity.
Paul Rhodes.impact: Clearer visibility and alignment; smarter decision-making; fewer surprises; Paul acts as communicator between regions (JLL doesn't communicate internally)
Paul Rhodes.leadership_endorsement: Paul explicitly called out as intentional strategy; leadership acknowledged gap

Kimberly Wittekind.title: Leadership Addition Without Client Cost
Kimberly Wittekind.description: Added Andrew Daria as project administrator (functions as account manager) by reallocating budget; no additional cost to client
Kimberly Wittekind.context: GE Healthcare was growing rapidly and Kimberly couldn't be in multiple places at once, but the unique scope (cleaning medical equipment, not buildings) requires specialized training and sign-offs. Rather than asking GE for budget approval (which could take months), she reallocated existing budget to add Andrew Daria as a project administrator who functions as an account manager. Andrew built trust with client POC Kellyanne, supported the difficult New Orleans transition, and provides $120K/year in value to GE at zero additional cost. This creative constraint management impressed Nick Viskovich and Val as a model for scaling leadership without client pushback.
Kimberly Wittekind.impact: $120k/year value-add to GE; huge asset for customer relationships and New Orleans transition support
Kimberly Wittekind.leadership_endorsement: Nick Viskovich praised; Val noted creative constraint management

Ana Sabater.title: Tiered Cost Initiatives (Platinum/Gold/Silver)
Ana Sabater.description: Delivered detailed cost optimization proposal to CBRE with tiered service models (Platinum, Gold, Silver) showing savings options

Giselle Langelier.title: Educating Client on Contract Language to Limit Credits/Scope Creep

Giselle Langelier.context: Medtronic contract has rate card with positions/hours and clause allowing credit requests for hours not worked. As long as SBM hits 90% of planned hours, client doesn't invoke clause. Small sites (like Irvine bell) notice absences and request credits incorrectly. Example: client asked for 25% credit for 1 of 4 people missing. Giselle educated: 'It doesn't work that way - it's by position (different hourly rates), and you have to account for OT from others covering the gap.' Supervisor position = $30/hr fully burdened, cleaner = $22/hr. Credit calculated by missing position rate minus OT from coverage. Giselle navigated this by: (1) maintaining transparency with hours reports, (2) educating clients on contract language, (3) staying above 90% threshold, and (4) leveraging strong relationships at most sites so clients don't invoke clause. This prevents margin erosion from improper credit requests while maintaining service quality.
Giselle Langelier.impact: Protected margin from improper credit requests; maintained client relationships despite aggressive contract clause

Dustin Smith.title: Office Transition: 55 Sites from Transitional to Sustaining State in 5 Months
Dustin Smith.description: Transitioned 55-site Amazon JLL office portfolio from August 2025 go-live to sustaining operations; integrated incumbent and external hire leaders; established operational stability across 24/7 office environments
Dustin Smith.context: Dustin joined mid-year 2025, went live August 2025 with 55 different office sites under Amazon JLL contract. Challenge: 'We had a lot of different new leaders coming in from either the incumbent or external hires.' Strategy: 'Transitioning to a sustaining state I would say was one of the biggest things that we focused on this year.' This involved: (1) One-on-one meetings with each site leader across entire portfolio to align on scope expectations and outcomes (started September 2025), (2) Scope alignment from frequency-based to outcome-based contract - 'Led to a lot of back and forth on what's in and out of scope... old work orders... team from incumbent was used to billing that,' (3) Shift and task alignment with Amazon 24/7 office schedules - 'They said for years they had been trying to understand Amazon shift schedule. It was our site leadership team that led those discussions,' (4) Management process enhancement - 'We took on a lot of incumbent managers, external hires, nobody with a lot of SBM stink on them... really doing deep dive training and making sure we're bringing our site managers up to SBM standard.' Result: Late December through January saw 'tremendous uptick' in ForSight quality/quantity of audits. Valarie: 'You do really good job typically controlling the room, controlling your customer and you come very well prepared with what you're going to say. You're well spoken. You remain calm.'
Dustin Smith.impact: 55 sites stabilized in 5 months; scope clarity achieved; Amazon shift schedules mapped; site managers elevated to SBM standard; ForSight audit quality increased
Dustin Smith.leadership_endorsement: Valarie praised Dustin's executive presence and preparation; Nicole: 'I've worked a whole ton with you over the years... excellent job'

Keith Deuber.title: Operationally Focused Leadership Team - Amazon SMEs

Keith Deuber.context: Strategic insight: 'This may be one of the only accounts where truly to the core, winning in Amazon is proving operations and your operational effectiveness.' Team building: 'Throughout the year, obviously Dustin coming on put everything in the hyperdrive. But throughout the year, bringing in Bill Darlington on the East Coast, five years in Amazon, operations through and through. Sam on the West Coast operation through and through, as well as Kathy Telford, who I brought in as MIT, spent eight years on the Amazon accounts. Really a true SME in the space as well as an SME in the categories that we want to break into a bit more, the MX LS, AM ZL and such like that.' Impact on perception: 'I really think this assisted, if not was a key driver in changing the perception of SBM and Amazon's eyes. We've went from having an account team to having a true operations team.' Site-level impact: 'This really successfully assisted in strengthening our site level management as well. These are operators. These are not guys that are going there and just, hey, you got to do this, got to do that, got to do this, they're going there and they're strengthening our on site management, they're mentoring them, they're showing them what to do, leading by example.' Result: 'The outcome of that is, I mean as we can see through peak through the beginning of this year, we're hitting the highest scores ever. I attest that to truly changing our leadership from strictly an account-based to strong operators, which again this account to grow is truly operational success equals growth.'
Keith Deuber.impact: Highest scores ever; perception transformed; site management strengthened; mentoring vs directing; operations = growth equation proven
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Valarie/Nicole: 'Keith, you come really strongly with the operational support. I feel almost every time you talk like if you said it, then it's facts. Like if you said that's the equipment problem, then that's what it is.'

Keith Deuber.title: Relationship Campaign - Operations Team Focus Over Category Team
Keith Deuber.description: Shifted relationship strategy from Amazon category team (who assign initial work) to operations teams (SPMs, RPMs, POLs) who influence site retention, loss, and RFP outcomes; established constant communication
Keith Deuber.context: Strategic shift: 'First and foremost, we were focusing on the wrong group per se. We were focusing on the category team. That category team is what assigns the work initially. But what we didn't have in focus was the operations teams. The operations teams, even though they do not single-handedly assign the work, they do have heavy influence throughout the year of losing sites, winning sites as well as coming up in the 2027 or 2026 RFP.' Target roles: 'We started to meet with the SPMs, the RPMs, as well as the POLs or the procurement operation leaders, and those three roles are really what determines success at a site. A POR can come in, they can stamp of approval or they can put you on a PIP.' Implementation: 'Throughout the year, beginning of the year and then Dustin obviously came on midway through the year and it kind of went into hyperdrive.' Result: 'We shifted our focus throughout 2025 to focus on the procurement operations and getting in front of them, having constant communication and really changing the perspective of Amazon about SBM starting with that group because they have the most I would say influence when it comes to category.'
Keith Deuber.impact: Relationships shifted to operations influencers; constant communication established; Amazon perception of SBM changed; positioned for 2026/2027 RFP success
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Strategic relationship targeting vs transactional category team focus

Keith Deuber.title: Strategic Operations Governance - Daily 15-Min Touchbases During Peak
Keith Deuber.description: Implemented Teams regional chats for real-time communication; established 15-minute daily touchbases during peak (started one month before); enabled shift-by-shift responsiveness; achieved zero escalations, 93.3% average, zero PIPs during peak
Keith Deuber.context: Amazon's unique risk: 'Amazon is different from other accounts. This is not an account that is, you know, hey, you have a year contract, three-year contract, we'll review it at the end of the contract. This is truly you fail two months in a row, you could potentially be on a pip. We're fending off a pip. You fail three in a row, you could potentially be kicked out of the site. So the typical standard on SBM internal communications just didn't work because it's a week to week contract, almost a shift by shift. You could drop a ball on a shift, next you know you're getting escalations.' Solution: '(1) Utilizing teams and setting up individual region by region teams chats to ensure that we're communicating real time. (2) During peak, starting about a month before peak, we set up 15 minute touch bases every single day with the teams, with the site managers, the regional, the area managers, just to make sure that we're communicating who was on site, where are the challenges, where are the gaps, when's the audit, what are the challenges of that week or that day?' Peak results: 'That truly I think was a driver into having 0 escalations during peak averaging at 93.3, which is significantly higher than we averaged during the peak prior and we were the only company that had zero sites on PIP throughout Peak, which is what's called out through our supplier Peak debrief with Marco Rosano.' This demonstrates Keith's understanding that Amazon requires fundamentally different communication cadence than typical SBM accounts.
Keith Deuber.impact: Zero escalations during peak; 93.3% average (significantly higher than prior peak); only company with zero PIPs; real-time shift-level responsiveness
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Marco Rosano called out SBM as only company with zero PIPs during supplier peak debrief

Keith Deuber.title: BI Dashboard Proof of Concept - Predictive Site Failure Analysis
Keith Deuber.description: Created BI dashboard with innovations team to digest Amazon's weekly scorecard and KPI documents; enables predictive analysis of site failure trends; tracks week-over-week patterns; supports data-driven operational decisions
Keith Deuber.context: Challenge: 'Amazon provides us with the weekly scorecard and then we also have to implement and send in a KPI document detailing out hours utilization, any service credits, staffing and such like that. What we were struggling with at the beginning of the year was digesting and actioning on those items, finding the key indicators to a site or trending to a site that is failing or catching it before it starts to have an escalation.' Solution: 'We created a BI dashboard with the innovations team that really allows us internally to track and trend and make predictive analysis on where a site's trending. Is it going to fail? What are the week over week fail trends and really put it on to a dashboard that allows us to make data-driven decisions to be able to sustain high operations.' This demonstrates Keith's strategic thinking to move from reactive to predictive operations management.
Keith Deuber.impact: Predictive site failure analysis; proactive intervention before escalations; data-driven decisions; week-over-week trend identification
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Innovation team collaboration; moves from reactive to predictive operations
