Tiffany Purifoy.title: Periodic Task Calendar - Eliminated Client Complaints at TRP Colorado
Tiffany Purifoy.description: Built calendar for TRP Colorado listing all periodic tasks and completion dates; sent to customer monthly with updates; reviewed in scorecard meetings; zero complaints since implementation; enhanced partnership through communication
Tiffany Purifoy.context: Problem: 'The lack of visibility to periodic tasks. This was a complaint, a consistent complaint in our Colorado location and the client was making us aware that they wanted to basically know when periodical tasks were completed so that they could then perform service validations.' Solution: 'What we did was build a calendar for the client listing all of the periodic tasks when they would be completed, and that calendar was sent to the customer with any necessary updates on a monthly basis and reviewed on our scorecard meetings.' Result: 'We've had zero complaints since we've implemented this new process and the client is very appreciative. Actually the partnership has grown stronger due to the enhanced communication.' Accountability: 'From an accountability standpoint, the periodical task should have been provided to our client ahead of time, not something that they should be asking or wondering if it was done. As an owner of the account, I should have ensured that (A) client asked for it twice and (B) ensure that these were plans and routes, some of them involved routes, were in place prior to the client requesting this information.'
Tiffany Purifoy.impact: Zero complaints since implementation; partnership strengthened through communication; client appreciative; proactive vs reactive approach established
Tiffany Purifoy.leadership_endorsement: Tiffany owns accountability - should have been proactive from start

Tiffany Purifoy.title: Mother's Room & Fitness Center Process - Prevented Repeat Privacy Incidents
Tiffany Purifoy.description: Implemented new entry process after two incidents at TRP (mother's room, fitness center); knock, wait 10 seconds, knock again, then enter even if IT light shows unoccupied; zero incidents since implementation; client appreciative
Tiffany Purifoy.context: Incidents: 'We've had two pretty important issues that occurred and one of them was an SBM entering a space. It was one of them was a mother's room. Another incident was a fitness center. Though I'm not sure if everyone's familiar with, there are lights on the door that let you know if it was occupied or not. In both incidences the IT stated that it was unoccupied. SBM employee knocked. There was no response. Employee entered to someone in the space.' Solution: 'Working directly with JLL and T. Rowe Price, we implemented a new process. That process basically states that employee is supposed to knock, wait a certain amount 10 seconds to enter, knock again and then enter the room because we obviously have keys to enter these spaces.' Result: 'Since this occurrence, both of those occurrences, there have been 0 incidences since implementation and the clients obviously really appreciate the implementation of this process.'
Tiffany Purifoy.impact: Zero privacy incidents since implementation; client appreciative; risk mitigated; process protects both occupants and SBM employees
Tiffany Purifoy.leadership_endorsement: Worked directly with JLL and TRP; client appreciative of process implementation

Greyson Wolff.description: Transformed Honda portfolio quality from 6 failed KPIs and 6 failed surveys in Q1 to only 3 failed KPIs and 1 failed survey in remaining 9 months; improved joint inspection scores from Q1 4.39 to Q2-Q4 4.54; achieved zero failed joint inspections all year
Greyson Wolff.context: Portfolio performance: '11 sites throughout 2025, we came through at a 4.94 performance score out of five for our scorecards. That's sitting at a 99 plus percent. Greyson Wolff.title: Aztec Sidewinder Equipment - 50% Floor Stripping Time Reduction
Greyson Wolff.description: Introduced Aztec Sidewinder equipment for VCT floor stripping; piloted July 2025 in Georgia; reduced time/labor by 50%; delivered $5K December shutdown savings; forecasting $20K+ annual savings; reduced high-visibility area downtime for client
Greyson Wolff.context: Challenge: '100,000 square feet of VCT across nine different states is really no joke and so we've had to get creative in how we can figure out a way to support that.' Innovation: 'The Aztec Sidewinder is what we have introduced into the portfolio here at the end of December and something that's really going to be able to change the dynamic of how we are completing service within these shutdown periods. We ran a trial of this last July in Georgia. Love the results that we saw. And so from that we ordered 2 units, one to be used between Alabama and Georgia, another unit to be used in Indiana and Ohio.' Results: 'We quickly found that we can reduce the time that we are spending, the time and labor in stripping floors by about 50%. Internally what this allowed us to do just in one shutdown here in December of 2025 is provide about $5000 of cost savings for us internally, we're forecasting that at about $20,000 plus in 2026.' Client impact: 'These are very high visibility areas that we are having to shut down for days on end in order to be able to get through the work. Our opportunity to be able to do these quicker while still delivering just as high of a quality result, if not better and then be able to reallocate resources back throughout the plant to complete additional projects is something that is felt not only with our team internally, but really throughout the entirety of the facilities and the facilities team as well as the end users. We've been able to dramatically increase the amount of work that we're able to complete within a very jammed packed 8 to 10 day shutdown period.'

And then as we closed out the year here in transition into 2026, Christopher Blankenship has been brought on board of our team in the Ohio market to help support some of the locations that don't have dedicated site management.' Financial impact: 'We have two positions in our area manager and our senior area manager, Blake Pacheco and William Smith. Scale: 5.3M sq ft campus, 175 restroom sets, 201 employees. 2026 initiatives: 'Scrape the Plate program initiative piloted in San Jose, sourcing new compostable liners, new trash/recycling/compost waste management program in San Jose and Boise, presenting cost savings to the client.'

Siddarth Shah.title: Paper Products Repurposing - Indirect Cost Savings & Carbon Footprint Reduction
Siddarth Shah.description: Instead of disposing paper products at 15% remaining, repurposing them for spills, leaks, and wipe-downs; reduces laundry costs, electricity usage, water consumption, and carbon footprint from rag washing
Siddarth Shah.context: Scale context: 'Having a site like Boise which stretches 5.3 million square feet, 175 sets of restrooms, the amount of toilet roll that gets used on a daily basis and the amount of waste of paper products was astronomical.' Innovation: 'We started repurposing our paper products. Any paper products that reach 15% need to be changed out and replenished, but we were not disposing those. We are now using, we are repurposing those for spills, any kind of leaks and any wipe downs that we need to do around the facility.' Impact: 'Might not seem like much, but this actually saves us doing laundry with our rags. It saves us with electricity. It actually reduces our carbon footprint. So there's a lot of cost savings indirectly. It's not necessarily monetary cost savings, but how are we using these products until we can actually dispose them without having impacts on using additional water and additional chemical going into our washing of the rags.' Client collaboration: 'We put together some information, data and presented it to the client. We made recommendations like maybe we should start using more bamboo based products, recycling products.'
Siddarth Shah.impact: Indirect cost savings across laundry/electricity/water; reduced carbon footprint; extended product lifecycle; data-driven sustainability presentation to client
Siddarth Shah.leadership_endorsement: Client approved after data presentation; sustainability alignment with Micron values

Jacob Reed.title: Proactive Maintenance Approach - $6K Sink to $120 Fixture Root Cause Analysis
Jacob Reed.description: Maintenance team shifted from reactive ticket chasing to proactive root cause analysis; example: instead of replacing $6K sink, identified calcium buildup and replaced $120 fixture; Tesla now requesting SBM partnership on broader facilities maintenance
Jacob Reed.context: Reactive past: 'For the longest time we've been really reactive and we kind of just taking things and kind of like how do we get to the next ticket. It costs like $6,000 for the sink.' Proactive approach: 'Edgar and his team actually took a second to say, hey, what do we find on the root of the problem? They remove the sink and find out there's just calcium buildup or inadequate pieces that people just kind of threw together because there was a deadline to get these areas turn over. Now we're actually bringing these permanent solutions that are actually instead of a $6,000 sink, it's replacing $120 fixture.' Client response: 'Now we're really getting our foothold on there where it's even getting to the part where they're like, hey, can you guys partner with facilities? Impact: 'It really just helps elevate us to where we're walking step with Tesla where it's how do we keep SBM growing with us.'

Jacob Reed.title: Rapid Scaling for Tesla Shop Openings - 2 Week Lead Time
Jacob Reed.description: Successfully scaled SBM operations for multiple Tesla shop openings (Cyber Cab station, new Model Y, battery expansion) with 2-week lead time from recruitment to fully operational; only vendor able to meet Tesla's rapid pace demands
Jacob Reed.context: Challenge: 'Tesla kind of exploded and revitalized their program. A lot of shops opened up for us and really was tasked with like how quickly can SBM scale this. Tesla likes to tell themselves they want to be first to everything. They want things done in such a rapid pace that you don't really have time to catch your breath. The opening of the Cyber Cab station, the envelopment of the new Model Y and the battery expansion pieces all deemed a pretty heavy need for additional scope and additional headcount.' One of the only vendors that could really meet those demands.' Jacob Reed.impact: Only vendor meeting Tesla's rapid expansion demands; 2-week recruitment-to-operational cycle; positioned SBM as scalable partner; supported Cyber Cab, Model Y, battery expansion launches
Jacob Reed.leadership_endorsement: Competitive differentiator for Tesla relationship; HR/recruiting/operations collaboration model

Jacob Reed.title: Flood Support Process - $200K Savings + 4 Hours to 45 Minutes Response
Jacob Reed.description: Developed systematic flood response process reducing response time from 4 hours to 45 minutes; saved Tesla $200K in 2025 by eliminating need for subcontractors; tracking and quantifying value monthly
Jacob Reed.context: Problem: 'With the amount of adjustments and demand that Tesla's doing of like moving the factory around daily, monthly, there's always someone that's hitting either a pipe or hitting fire sprinklers, releasing hundreds of thousands of gallons of water. It became just an ordeal where production is down. Everybody's just waiting. The cars won't move because there's water in the way.' Old process: 'In the past it's taken us about four hours to get all this water kind of in once to center, get it all taken care of, get it all soaked up and moved on.' New process: 'Now where it's down to like 45 minutes to an hour, hour at the max. There's a process, there's a direction and there's guidance from our team. Our team looks like they're supposed to be there. People get excited where they're like SBM's here, they're going to take care of this water. We can keep moving from production because everybody's getting hounded in the background of like, why aren't these cars being made?' Value quantification: 'We were happy to announce to them that we saved them about $200K in savings. It wasn't necessarily built into our scope when we first started. We were just there for more of a residual water cleanup to where we took on the actual flooding in itself. They're not having to bring out any subvendors.' Tracking: 'We're able to give them that like a solid number. Now we're tracking that daily, monthly for them to be able to see that we are bringing that value add.'

Jacob Reed.title: Cost Savings Strategy Shift - Budget Alignment vs Egregious Demands
Jacob Reed.description: Shifted narrative from client-demanded cost savings ($600K+/month expectations) to proactive budget alignment with factory schedules; delivered $250K in holiday/shutdown savings while protecting operational integrity
Jacob Reed.context: Old approach problem: 'The real goal internally for me is getting away from planning Tesla a lot of these cost savings. When we first started the account it was like how can we get SBM to give us more than $600,000 a month back in cost savings? It was like an expectation for you guys to just give us a giant amount of money back. It became like a nightmare trying to move things around.' New approach: 'I really wanted to show them the overall leader budget, being able to tell them these are necessities that we need. We're not over asking. We're not trying to take advantage. It was more or less aligning with them. We'll give you the cost savings that structure with how the factory operates, IE like holidays and factory shutdowns. We're able to go in there, produce some savings for them and say like, you guys are down, we see that we're not going to overstaff for a factory that's dead.' Results: 'Aligning with them on their schedules, kind of integrating into what Tesla's doing and kind of getting ahead of it instead of asking the customer how much do you need to save. It's more or less like, hey, what does the schedule looks like? Oh great, with that kind of reductions I can save you guys as much money. That one also came out to about $250K with the reduction there. Those were like just for major holidays, Christmas, Thanksgiving, 4th of July, MLK Day and Veteran's Day.' Philosophy: 'It's a really good way to just not allow them to push us around and kind of put our foot down and say, hey, we're going to move in the right direction of the budgets that we asked for are lean because they reflect exactly what we need and any kind of cost savings we'll be more than happy to give back to you, but those are justified and not like being over budgeted.'
